p: Meanwhile, changes in the behavior of disease vectors, particularly mosquitoes, are another effect of temperature, precipitation, and water quality alterations. For instance, high temperature accelerates the larval development of Anopheles gambiae s.s. mosquitoes, a vector for malaria [35]. Moreover, higher levels of precipitation are found to accelerate the population growth of mosquitoes carrying dengue, scrub typhus, and Japanese encephalitis, thereby facilitating their rapid spread [32]. Similar with water- and food-borne diseases, mosquito-borne diseases can result in more aggressive presentations of vector-borne infections in PLHIVs [36].
